The next head, Antiochus, went beyond this ambiguous position, and abandoned scepticism alto- gether. Contradicting Philo, he maintained that the true tradition of Plato had been lost, and pro- fessed to recover it, calling his school the ‘Old Acade1ny.' But his reading of the history of philo- sophy was hardly more accurate than Philo's. He asserted that the teachings of the older Academics and Peripatetics and of the Stoics were, in Ethics at all events, substantially the same, and that Zeno had borrowed his tenets from his predecessors,
